 I just wanted to point out that the AFL CIO is run by people who do not work for minimum wage but like xamnr said, 3-6 times the minimum wage. Who the heck wouldn't want the minimum wage raised if it is reflected 3 to 6 times in their own paycheck?!? A brief example:
 A skilled painter can do a job in the same amount of time it takes 3 unskilled painters. The unskilled painters charge minimum wage per hour for their job. It is only justified that the skilled painter should charge 3 times the minimum wage for his services per hour (maybe a little less to make his prices competitive). So he charges around $15.45 an hour for his service. (5.15 x 3 = 15.45) The minimum wage is raised to the new indexed $7.25 to help the little man. Well, the unskilled painters now make $2.10 more per hour while the skilled painter makes $6.30 more per hour. Of course the painter would be for a minimum wage raise. I just want to know how this closes the gap between the poor and the wealthier. In the short term, the little man loses jobs and in the long term, the dollar becomes less valuable, prices adjust to the new minimum wage, and the gap between the classes has made zero to negative gain.
